Hi Dave,

Just a quick note on a couple of things.  First, thanks again for all of
your work on this project.  At the Symposium in Japan, I was telling
everyone who would listen that I thought Cantera was the next big thing in
combustion modeling, and after getting a bit more serious in the last few
days, I am more convinced.

I believe I told you that my interest fell into two categories.  First, we
are interested in diffusion flame chemistry, and creating a 1-D flame (and
then, hopefully, 2-D)  is my goal.  In the short term, I have been
interested in "porting" to Delphi, a language much more popular in the
scientific community in Europe than it is here.  That all might change, as
KYLIX, the version of Delphi that runs on LINUX, grows in popularity.

Teh ports can take a few different paths.  Unfortunately  the way C++ does
classes is just different enough from how Delphi does Object Classes, that
some work is needed in the transition.  ("Flattening" seems to be the
popular verb for this.) From what I can tell, this is what you have done for
the MATLAB interface.  This might be the ultimate solution, but not trivial.
(The challenge is creating an interface to the DLL from the important header
files.)

In the short term, I have found a set of Delphi components called "Python
for Delphi" that provides an easy interface between Python scripts and the
GUI of Delphi.  I have written a "wrapper" for the 1-D premix code that
provides visual tools for setting up a flame calculation, running it, and
plotting the results (without leaving the program.)  As I clean this up,
this might be a useful tool for others in the users group, particularly as
an educational tool.  Let me know if this is of interest and I will clean it
up and send it out to you.

My question of the day is this: how hard would it be to set up the
cpounterflow problem (either premixed or non-premixed.)?  Is this something
you have already started in on?










----- Original Message -----
From: "Dave Goodwin" <dgoodwin@...>
To: <cantera@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Wednesday, November 06, 2002 8:54 AM
Subject: [cantera] Short-term Research Position at Caltech


>
> I am looking for someone to work on a new DARPA-funded collaborative
> program between Prof. Bill Goddard (Chemistry, Caltech), myself, and
> a couple of others. The work will involve developing methods to
> extract reduced reaction mechanisms for energetic materials directly
> from reactive molecular dynamics simulation data, and will involve
> working closely with the Goddard group.
>
> The position is available immediately. Unfortunately this is a short-
> duration program, and will likely end at the end of July, 2003.
>
> If you are interested in spending half a year or so at Caltech, and
> have experience in kinetics, computational methods, etc., please let
> me know off-line (dgoodwin@...) and I can provide more
> information.
>
>
>
>
